Underwater archaeology
	New functions relating to underwater archaeology
		Amend section 33 of the National Heritage Act [1983 (c.47)](/id/ukpga/1983/47?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (generalfunctions of the Historic Buildings and Monuments Commission for England) asfollows.
		In subsection (8), in the definition of “ancient monument”, after “site”insert “(including any site comprising, or comprising the remains of, anyvehicle, vessel, aircraft or other movable structure or part thereof)”.
		After that subsection insert—
		In this section references to ancient monuments in England include ancientmonuments in, on or under the seabed within the seaward limits of the UnitedKingdom territorial waters adjacent to England.
		For this purpose the Secretary of State may, by order, determine (or makeprovision for determining) any boundary between—
			the parts of the United Kingdom territorial waters which are to be treatedas adjacent to England, and
			those which are not.
		The power to make an order under subsection (10) shall be exercisable bystatutory instrument which shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of aresolution of either House of Parliament.”
	Amendments consequential on section 1
		In section 34 of the National Heritage Act [1983 (c.47)](/id/ukpga/1983/47?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (Commission toexercise certain ministerial functions)—
			in subsection (3), after “site” insert “(including any site comprising, orcomprising the remains of, any vehicle, vessel, aircraft or other movablestructure or part thereof)”; and
			after that subsection insert—
				“(3A)In this section references to ancient monuments in England includeancient monuments in, on or under the seabed within the seaward limits of theUnited Kingdom territorial waters adjacent to England; and an order undersection 33(10) applies for the purposes of this subsection as it applies forthe purposes of section 33(9).”
		In section 17 of the Ancient Monuments and Archaeological Areas Act [1979(c. 46)](/id/ukpga/1979/46?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (agreementconcerning ancient monuments and land in their vicinity), after subsection (9)insert—
		References in this section to an ancient monument situated in Englandinclude any such monument situated in, on or under the seabed within theseaward limits of the United Kingdom territorial waters adjacent to England;and an order under section 33(10) of the National Heritage Act 1983 (ordersdetermining limits of waters adjacent to England) applies for the purposes ofthis subsection as it applies for the purposes of section 33(9) of that Act.”
		In section 24 of that Act (expenditure by Secretary of State or localauthority on acquisition and preservation of ancient monuments, etc), aftersubsection (3A) insert—
		“(3AA)The reference in subsection (3A) above to a monument situated in Englandincludes any monument situated in, on or under the seabed within the seawardlimits of the United Kingdom territorial waters adjacent to England; and anorder under section 33(10) of the National Heritage Act 1983 (ordersdetermining limits of waters adjacent to England) applies for the purposes ofthis subsection as it applies for the purposes of section 33(9) of that Act.”
	Exercise of certain ministerial functions
		This section applies to any administrative function exercisable by theSecretary of State (whether by virtue of an enactment or otherwise) inrelation to any ancient monument which is in, on or under the seabed withinthe seaward limits of the United Kingdom territorial waters.
		If the Secretary of State directs the Historic Buildings and MonumentsCommission for England (established by section 32 of the National Heritage Act1983) to exercise functions to which this section applies and which arespecified in the direction, in relation to any ancient monument or class ofancient monument so specified, the Commission shall exercise them on hisbehalf in such manner as he may from time to time direct.
		In this section “ancient monument” means any structure, work, site(including any site comprising, or comprising the remains of, any vehicle,vessel, aircraft or other movable structure or part thereof) or area which inthe opinion of the Secretary of State is, or may be, of historic,architectural, traditional, artistic or archaeological interest.
		This section does not apply to—
			a function of making regulations or other instruments of a legislativecharacter;
			a function to which section 34 of the National Heritage Act [1983 (c.47)](/id/ukpga/1983/47?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (power toauthorise Commission to exercise certain functions of management exercisableby the Secretary of State in respect of England) applies.
		In relation to any matter as respects which the Commission act by virtue ofa direction under this section, the Commission shall enjoy the sameprivileges, immunities and exemptions as those enjoyed in relation to thatmatter by the Secretary of State.
		Paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 3 to the National Heritage Act 1983 (Commissionnot to be regarded as servant or agent of the Crown) is subject to subsection(5).
		Any direction given under this section shall be in writing.
		Any power conferred by this section to give a direction shall include apower to vary or revoke the direction.
		The Commission shall comply with any direction given under this section.
Trading functions
	New trading functions of the Commission
		In section 33 of the National Heritage Act 1983 (Commission’s generalfunctions), in subsection (2), after paragraph (d) insert—
			may produce souvenirs relating to ancient monuments or historic buildingssituated in England and sell souvenirs.”
		After that section insert—
		“33AFunctions relating to foreign monuments and buildings
			The Commission may—
				produce and publish, or sell, books, films or other informative materialrelating to foreign ancient monuments or foreign historic buildings;
				produce or sell souvenirs relating to such monuments or buildings;
				provide (whether on payment or otherwise) advice, assistance or otherservices in respect of, or information relating to, such monuments orbuildings.
			For this purpose—
				“ancient monument” and “historic building” have the meaning given insection 33(8), and
				an ancient monument or historic building is “foreign” if it is notsituated—
				in the United Kingdom, or
				in the case of a monument, in, on or under the seabed within the seawardlimits of the territorial waters of the United Kingdom.
		BPowers to exploit intangible assets
			The Commission may exploit any intellectual property, or any otherintangible asset, relating to ancient monuments or historic buildings.
			In subsection (1) the references to “ancient monuments” and “historicbuildings” are to ancient monuments and historic buildings within the meaningof section 33(8) that—
				are situated—
				in England, or
				in the case of monuments, in, on or under the seabed within the seawardlimits of the United Kingdom territorial waters adjacent to England, or
				are foreign ancient monuments or foreign historic buildings within themeaning of section 33A(2)(b).
			An order under section 33(10) applies for the purposes of subsection (2) asit applies for the purposes of section 33(9).
			In this section “intellectual property” means—
				any patent, trade mark, registered design, copyright, design right, rightin performance or plant breeder’s right, and
				any rights under the law of a country outside the United Kingdom whichcorrespond or are similar to those falling within paragraph (a).
			This section is without prejudice to any power of the Commission to doanything authorised by this section by virtue of section 33 or 33A.”
	Objects of companies formed by the Commission
		Amend section 35 of the National Heritage Act [1983 (c.47)](/id/ukpga/1983/47?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (power ofCommission to form companies) as follows.
		In subsection (2)—
			in paragraph (a) for “in England” substitute “, or sale,”;
			after paragraph (a) insert—
			the provision (whether on payment or otherwise) of advice, assistance orother services in respect of, or information relating to, ancient monuments orhistoric buildings,”;
			in paragraph (b)—
			the words “in England” are repealed, and
			after “buildings” insert “, or sale of souvenirs”; and
			for paragraph (c) substitute—
			the exploitation of any intellectual property, or any other intangibleasset, relating to ancient monuments or historic buildings, and”.
		After subsection (3) insert—
			“(3A)In subsection (2), the references to “ancient monuments” and “historicbuildings” are to those which—
			are situated—
			in England, or
			in the case of monuments, in, on or under the seabed within the seawardlimits of the United Kingdom territorial waters adjacent to England, or
			are foreign ancient monuments or foreign historic buildings within themeaning of section 33A(2)(b).
			(3B)An order under section 33(10) applies for the purposes of subsection (3A)as it applies for the purposes of section 33(9).
			(3C)In this section “intellectual property” means—
			any patent, trade mark, registered design, copyright, design right, rightin performance or plant breeder’s right, and
			any rights under the law of a country outside the United Kingdom whichcorrespond or are similar to those falling within paragraph (a).”
Protected wrecks
	Assistance in relation to protected wrecks
		After section 33B of the National Heritage Act [1983 (c.47)](/id/ukpga/1983/47?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (powers toexploit intangible assets), inserted by section 4 of this Act, insert—
		“33CAssistance in relation to protected wrecks
			The Commission may defray or contribute towards the cost of—
				any survey, excavation or other investigation undertaken in respect of anyprotected wreck;
				the removal of any protected wreck or of any part of any protected wreck toanother place for the purpose of preserving it; or
				the preservation and maintenance of any protected wreck.
			In this section—
				  * “maintenance” includes repairing and covering in of a protected wreck and the doing of any other act or thing which may be required for the purpose of repairing the wreck or protecting it from decay or injury; and
				  * “protected wreck” means any site which—
				comprises, or comprises the remains of, any vessel or part thereof which isprotected by an order under section 1 of the Protection of Wrecks Act [1973(c. 33)](/id/ukpga/1973/33?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") designatingan area round the site as a restricted area, and
				is in, on or under the seabed within the seaward limits of the United Kingdomterritorial waters adjacent to England.
			An order under section 33(10) applies for the purposes of paragraph (b) ofthe definition of “protected wreck” in subsection (2) as it applies for thepurposes of section 33(9).”
Functions to support other heritage organisations
	New functions to support other heritage organisations
		In section 33 of the National Heritage Act [1983 (c.47)](/id/ukpga/1983/47?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (Commission’sgeneral functions), in subsection (2), after paragraph (e), inserted bysection 4 of this Act, insert—
			may defray or contribute to the cost of any activity undertaken by anotherperson if the activity—
			relates to ancient monuments or historic buildings, and
			is of a kind which the Commission may itself undertake.”
Supplementary
	Short title, commencement and extent
		This Act may be cited as the National Heritage Act 2002.
		This Act shall come into force at the end of the period of two monthsbeginning with the day on which it is passed.
		Any amendment or repeal made by this Act shall have the same extent as theenactment to which it relates.
		Section 3 and this section extend to England and Wales, Scotland andNorthern Ireland.
		Subject to subsections (3) and (4), this Act extends to England and Walesonly.
